ranked_diseases.explanation: Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 1 (TREX1-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 2 (RNASEH2B-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 3 (RNASEH2C-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 4 (RNASEH2A-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 5 (SAMHD1-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 6 (ADAR-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 7 (IFIH1-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 8 (LSm11-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome (AGS) is a severe inflammatory encephalopathy that frequently presents with early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination, precisely matching the patient's phenotypic features. Type 9 (RNU7-1-related) is one of several genetic causes with a similar presentation.

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher Disease (PMD) is a classic X-linked hypomyelinating leukodystrophy characterized by profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and severe CNS hypomyelination. Seizures are a common feature, and can manifest as epileptic encephalopathy in severe forms.

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like Disease 1 (PMLD1) is an autosomal recessive hypomyelinating leukodystrophy with a clinical presentation very similar to PMD, including profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and CNS hypomyelination. Epileptic encephalopathy is also a recognized feature.

Hypomyelinating Leukodystrophy 7 (POLR3A-related) is part of the 4H leukodystrophy spectrum, characterized by significant CNS hypomyelination, profound global developmental delay, and hypotonia. Seizures and epileptic encephalopathy are common neurological manifestations.

Hypomyelinating Leukodystrophy 8 (POLR3B-related) is another disorder within the 4H leukodystrophy spectrum, sharing key features with HLD7 including CNS hypomyelination, profound global developmental delay, hypotonia, and a propensity for seizures and epileptic encephalopathy.

Hypomyelinating Leukodystrophy 11 (POLR1C-related) is part of the POLR3-related leukodystrophies, which are defined by CNS hypomyelination, profound developmental delay, hypotonia, and can include epileptic encephalopathy.

Vanishing White Matter Disease (VWMD) is a progressive leukoencephalopathy characterized by CNS hypomyelination, profound global developmental delay (often with regression), and hypotonia. Seizures, including epileptic encephalopathy, are common, especially in severe early-onset forms.

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Hypomyelination with atrophy of basal ganglia and cerebellum
ranked_diseases.explanation: Hypomyelination with atrophy of basal ganglia and cerebellum (H-ABC) is caused by TUBB4A mutations and presents with CNS hypomyelination, developmental delay, hypotonia, and often movement disorders. Seizures can occur and contribute to the neurological phenotype.

Multiple Sulfatase Deficiency (MSD) is a lysosomal storage disorder that can cause severe neurodegeneration, developmental delay/regression, hypotonia, seizures (including refractory epilepsy), and white matter abnormalities, which can include hypomyelination or dysmyelination.
